conclusion: Analyze the motion of the positively charged ball under the influence of the electric field and gravity to calculate the change in electric potential energy.

The image shows a uniform electric field directed horizontally to the right. A positively charged ball with mass \( m \) starts from point \( O \) with an initial velocity \( v_{0} \) at an angle \( \theta \) to the left, opposite to the electric field.
The ball is subject to two forces: the electric force \( q\mathbf{E} \) and gravity \( mg \). The net force is \( mg - qE \cos \theta \), directed downward.
The ball's motion can be described by the equation of motion under constant acceleration: \( y = v_{0} \sin \theta t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \).
At the highest point, \( v_y = 0 \), so \( 0 = v_{0} \sin \theta - g t \). Solving for \( t \), we get \( t = \frac{v_{0} \sin \theta}{g} \).
The change in electric potential energy \( \Delta U \) is given by \( \Delta U = qEy \).
At the highest point, \( y = v_{0} \sin \theta \frac{v_{0} \sin \theta}{g} \).
Thus, the change in electric potential energy is \( \Delta U = qE \left( v_{0} \sin \theta \right) \left( \frac{v_{0} \sin \theta}{g} \right) \).
This simplifies to \( \Delta U = \frac{1}{2} m v_{0}^2 \sin^2 \theta \).
Since the ball is positively charged, \( q = m \), and \( \Delta U = \frac{1}{2} m v_{0}^2 \sin^2 \theta \).
The difference in electric potential energy at the highest point compared to point \( O \) is \( \frac{1}{2} m v_{0}^2 \sin^2 \theta \).
